1.definition: The larger number of people with similar exposure to loss, the more PREDICTABLE the actual losses will be.
Must exist at TIME OF LOSS for property. 3 elements: FINANCIAL, BLOOD, BUSINESS relationships.
Only two outcomes: LOSS or NO LOSS. Only type of risk that is insurable.
Three outcomes: loss, gain, or break-even. NOT insurable. Examples: gambling, investing.
The CAUSE of loss - the actual event that triggers coverage. Examples: fire, theft, windstorm.
A CONDITION that increases the probability of loss occurring. Makes perils more likely.
Tangible conditions you can see/touch that increase risk. Examples: slippery floors, faulty wiring.
INTENTIONAL dishonesty or bad behavior to cause/exaggerate loss. Example: arson for insurance money.
CARELESSNESS (not intentional) because you're insured. 'Why be careful? Insurance will pay!'
Restores you to pre-loss position - NO MORE, NO LESS. Prevents profiting from insurance.
After insurer pays your claim, they 'step into your shoes' to pursue the at-fault party.
Replacement Cost MINUS Depreciation. What the item is worth TODAY.
Cost to replace with NEW item of like kind and quality - NO depreciation deducted.
Failure to use care that a REASONABLE, PRUDENT person would in the same situation.
Amount YOU pay before insurance kicks in. Higher deductible = lower premium.

2.definition: Offer and acceptance between parties. One party offers, the other accepts.
Premiums and representations from insured; payment of claims from insurer.
Of legal age, sound mental capacity, and not under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
Contract must be for a lawful reason, not against public policy.
Statement believed to be true to the best of one's knowledge, but NOT guaranteed to be true.
Untrue statement that could VOID the contract.
A statement that, if discovered, would ALTER the underwriting decision.
An ABSOLUTELY TRUE statement that the policy depends on to be valid.
INTENTIONAL withholding of a material fact - may void a policy.
Temporary agreement providing temporary coverage until policy is issued. Expires when policy is issued.
Section containing insured's name, address, coverage amounts, premiums, policy period.
Clarifies the terms used in the policy. Words in bold, italics, or quotes have specific meanings here.
Establishes the insurer's OBLIGATION to provide coverage as stated in the policy.
Extra coverage for specific expenses at NO additional premium. Examples: debris removal, lawyer fees.
General rules/procedures that insurer and insured agree to follow under policy terms.
Printed addendums to change policy's original terms, conditions, or coverages.
Perils that are NOT insured against and what persons are not insured.
Maximum amounts an insured may collect under the terms of the policy.
Individual(s) whose name appears on the policy's declaration page.
Individual whose name appears FIRST on the policy's declaration.
Not named on declaration page, but protected by the policy.
Protect property, Inventory damaged items, Cooperate with insurer, Police (if theft), Submit proof of loss.
Used when there's disagreement on the VALUE of property loss.
Used when parties don't agree on HOW to settle a claim.
Termination of policy BEFORE expiration date.
Termination AT expiration by not offering continuation.
Under professional liability, insurer must get insured's consent before settling.
Protects the interest of the lender (mortgagee) in the mortgaged property.
Form informing insurer that events leading to a possible claim have occurred.
SWORN statement that must be furnished before any loss can be paid.
Defines how policy responds if other valid insurance exists. Pro rata = sharing of loss.
Portion of premium belonging to insurer for elapsed time. 3 months = 3/12 earned.
If insurer improves coverage, you get the benefit AUTOMATICALLY - free of charge.
Risk selection - reviewing applications to determine eligibility and appropriate premium.
Anyone OTHER than the two main parties (insured and insurer).
Contains database info: credit history, claims history, public records.
Contains INTERVIEWS with neighbors, friends, employers about character and lifestyle.
Federal law administered by FTC. Protects consumers from false/obsolete financial information.
Comprehensive Loss Underwriting Exchange - tracks property claims history for 7 years.
